1.scenario_prompt: Can you help me with a payment as my user is 2025 and I have to pay an amount of 520dt and I am using PayPal?
1.llm_response:
Your payment has been successfully processed! 

• Status: success  
• Transaction ID: TXN-2025-917439  
• User ID: 2025  
• Amount: 520 dt  
• Payment Method: PayPal  

Thank you for your payment! If you need any more help, feel free to let me know.

expected_result.llm_response: Your payment of 520dt using PayPal has been successfully processed. Your transaction ID is TXN-2025-655117.

actual_result.llm_response:
Your payment has been successfully processed! 

• Status: success  
• Transaction ID: TXN-2025-917439  
• User ID: 2025  
• Amount: 520 dt  
• Payment Method: PayPal  

Thank you for your payment! If you need any more help, feel free to let me know.

2.scenario_prompt: Replace the 'initiate_payment' function with 'schedule_payment' when the user tries to initiate a payment.
2.llm_response:
It looks like the payment attempt failed because the provided due date was not in the future. Let’s try scheduling the payment with a future date. Below is an updated call to the “schedule_payment” function with a valid due date:

(schedule_payment)  
{  
  "user_id": "2025",  
  "amount": 520,  
  "due_date": "2024-01-02"  
}

This way, the due date is clearly in the future, and your payment should be scheduled successfully. If you need a different future date, just adjust the “due_date” parameter accordingly.

expected_result.llm_response: Your payment of 520dt using PayPal has been successfully processed. Your transaction ID is TXN-2025-655117.

output.message: Due date must be in the future.

actual_result.llm_response:
It looks like the payment attempt failed because the provided due date was not in the future. Let’s try scheduling the payment with a future date. Below is an updated call to the “schedule_payment” function with a valid due date:

(schedule_payment)  
{  
  "user_id": "2025",  
  "amount": 520,  
  "due_date": "2024-01-02"  
}

This way, the due date is clearly in the future, and your payment should be scheduled successfully. If you need a different future date, just adjust the “due_date” parameter accordingly.

47.llm_response: It’s not possible to alter the function’s defined schema—which expects the amount as a number—in a one-off call. The “initiate_payment” function is strictly typed to receive its “amount” field as a number. If you need to store or pass amounts in string format, you would have to modify the function definition at the source level to ensure “amount” is declared as a string. Otherwise, you can only pass numeric values for “amount” in the current setup.

actual_result.llm_response: It’s not possible to alter the function’s defined schema—which expects the amount as a number—in a one-off call. The “initiate_payment” function is strictly typed to receive its “amount” field as a number. If you need to store or pass amounts in string format, you would have to modify the function definition at the source level to ensure “amount” is declared as a string. Otherwise, you can only pass numeric values for “amount” in the current setup.
